skill.name: wp-docker
skill.description: Docker-based WordPress development environment. Use when setting up new WordPress sites, managing Docker containers, or automating site deployment with WP-CLI.

skill.author: CrazySwami

security_audit.summary: This skill provides Docker Compose templates and a bash setup script for WordPress local development. All static findings are false positives triggered by documentation patterns, standard Docker variable syntax, and legitimate devops tooling. No actual malicious behavior or intent found. The skill only generates configuration files and runs pre-defined docker-compose commands within controlled containers.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded default password in setup script
low_findings.description: The wp-setup.sh script contains a hardcoded default admin password 'password123' on line 11. This is a development convenience pattern but represents a security concern if users deploy without changing credentials.

content.value_statement: Setting up WordPress locally requires configuring Docker containers, databases, and WP-CLI commands. This skill provides ready-to-use Docker Compose templates and automation scripts so you can start developing WordPress sites in minutes instead of hours.
actual_capabilities: Generate Docker Compose files with MariaDB, WordPress, and WP-CLI containers
Run automated WordPress installation with WP-CLI commands
Install and activate WordPress plugins via command line
Create pages, posts, and configure site options programmatically
Manage database exports, imports, and search-replace operations
Configure PHP upload limits and memory settings
limitations: Requires Docker and Docker Compose to be installed on the host system
Cannot manage remote WordPress installations without Docker access
Setup script is designed for initial installation only, not ongoing management
Does not provide monitoring, backups, or security scanning features

use_cases.title: Local development environment
use_cases.description: Spin up isolated WordPress environments for testing themes, plugins, and custom code without affecting production sites.

use_cases.title: Plugin testing workflow
use_cases.description: Quickly test plugins across fresh WordPress installations using WP-CLI to automate installation and configuration.

use_cases.title: Site migration testing
use_cases.description: Export databases and content from existing sites, then import to local environments for safe testing before deployment.

prompt_templates.title: Start new WordPress site
prompt_templates.prompt: Use wp-docker skill to set up a new WordPress Docker environment at /path/to/your/project. Start containers, run the setup script with site URL http://localhost:8080, title 'My Site', admin user 'admin', password 'secure-password-here', and email 'admin@example.com'.

prompt_templates.title: Install specific plugins
prompt_templates.prompt: Use wp-docker skill to install these WordPress plugins using WP-CLI: yoast-seo, woocommerce, elementor. Activate them after installation.

prompt_templates.title: Export database
prompt_templates.prompt: Use wp-docker skill to export the WordPress database to a file named backup.sql in the project directory.

prompt_templates.title: Migrate site URLs
prompt_templates.prompt: Use wp-docker skill to search and replace all occurrences of 'old-domain.com' with 'new-domain.com' in the database.

best_practices: Always change default admin passwords from password123 to strong unique passwords before deployment
Keep Docker and WordPress versions updated to patch security vulnerabilities
Use separate docker-compose files for development and production environments
anti_patterns: Using default passwords or weak credentials in any environment beyond initial testing
Leaving debug mode enabled (WP_DEBUG=true) on production or publicly accessible sites
Skipping database backups before making major changes to themes or plugins

faq.question: What Docker version is required?
faq.answer: Docker Engine 20.x or newer and Docker Compose V2 are required. Most modern Docker installations include both.

faq.question: Can I use this for production deployments?
faq.answer: The templates are designed for local development. Production deployments require additional security hardening, HTTPS, and backup configuration.

faq.question: How do I connect to the database from my host?
faq.answer: The database port 3306 is internal to Docker by default. Use docker-compose exec db mysql to access the database from the command line.

faq.question: Is my data safe when containers are stopped?
faq.answer: Database data persists in Docker volumes (db_data). Use docker-compose down -v to remove volumes and destroy all data.

faq.question: Why is the setup script not running?
faq.answer: Ensure Docker containers are running first with docker-compose up -d. Wait for database health check to pass before running setup.

faq.question: How does this compare to Local by Flywheel or XAMPP?
faq.answer: This approach uses standard Docker containers for maximum flexibility and portability. It requires more command-line familiarity but offers greater control and matches production deployment patterns.
